data.title: Nikon Self-Service
data.meta_description: Im not sure if Nikon has had this open but, according to NR, Nikon opened up a self service page on their website. [img]https://nikonrumors.com/wp...
data.text:
ArizonaImage

Offline

  

: Off

p.1 #3 · p.1 #3 · Nikon Self-Service

bernardl wrote:

This is actually extremely surprising.

If confirmed it would be the sign of a very deep change in the mindset of Nikon, one that I thought would never ever happen with any major Japanese camera manufacturer.

Apparently, some legislation was passed in Europe to push right to repair so perhaps more companies will follow suit. Kind of like the USB-C forcing Apple to comply.

Max Power

Offline

  

: Off

p.1 #7 · p.1 #7 · Nikon Self-Service

In the automotive world, right to repair just allows independent shops to have access to the equipment required to repair a manufacturer's line of vehicles, not consumers. It gives consumers the choice of shops, not just dealerships. Not sure if right to repair has much to do with consumers. Speaking for the US, btw, so every country might have its own unique legislation.

Nikon1960

Offline

   

: On

p.1 #8 · p.1 #8 · Nikon Self-Service

Max Power wrote:

In the automotive world, right to repair just allows independent shops to have access to the equipment required to repair a manufacturer's line of vehicles, not consumers. It gives consumers the choice of shops, not just dealerships. Not sure if right to repair has much to do with consumers. Speaking for the US, btw, so every country might have its own unique legislation.

At the moment, Nikon customers have no choice of shop whatsoever.

No shop or individual is allowed to buy most parts needed to service cameras, aside from purely cosmetic items like rubber rings.

So anyone who has a broken Nikon product is forced to send it into Nikon USA directly and pay whatever they deem the repair should cost. And if you happen to have a grey-market item, you cannot get service at all if its not for a recall. Its very frustrating, as its impossible to differentiate between a USA model lens and grey market for many of Nikons most expensive models.

ArizonaImage

Its very frustrating, as its impossible to differentiate between a USA model lens and grey market for many of Nikons most expensive models. ...Show more →

IIRC, the grey market made on the same assembly line as US destined Nikons, just with different firmware/serial/conformity labels.
